Posts.Content: Aug 22, 2011 02:07PM Cat123 wrote: I am crying right now as I read your post.  I am so sorry for your loss.....my deepest condolences for you and your family.  I lost my mother to cancer in 2008 and I know how difficult this is.  Thank you for you advice in your post.  I am 47 and have stage 111 breast cancer and just finished my treatment.  I applaud your mother for taking her own route in life and doing what she thought was best....that takes a strong person.  You have to do what you feel is right and what you believe in.  God Bless to you and your family and you will see you mother again one day. Hugs to you
Posts.Title: My Mother Is Sleeping Now BrokenHeart marieibrahim

Posts.Content: Aug 22, 2011 05:16PM Cat123 wrote: Hi Lena, I was quite burnt during rads.  I applied saline solution a few times a day plus Glaxal Base moisturing cream (they recommended this) and this helped alot.  Even though I was burnt and peeling, it got better quicker than I expected.
Posts.Title: July 2011 rads Merilee jankc

Posts.Content: Feb 8, 2012 10:59PM Cat123 wrote: My thoughts and prayers are with you Butterflylady......I wish we didn't have to fight this.
Posts.Title: Stage 3 again 6 years later ButterflyLady Kodapants

Posts.Content: Mar 13, 2011 01:17AM Cat123 wrote: I am so sorry that you are going through all of this!  I am 47 and single but I have some great friends.  It must be difficult with relationship problems on top of the treatments.  You are a strong woman!  This guy is making it sound like it is all about him but some people do that.  I am not sure of where you want to take this relationship but you have to think about yourself right now.  You are your number one priority.  I was laid off of my job about 3 and half week before diagnosis and have worked with lawyers to get my short and long term disabily....a nightmare!  My surgery went so well and my chemo has gone well too....two more to go!  We are all here for you if you want to rant.  I can't believe someone close to you is not being supportive.....some people just don't get it.  Sometimes this diagnosis makes you re-evaluate relationships and sometimes you have to get rid of toxic people but that is up to you to decide.  You will get through this with flying colors!  Hugs to you!
Posts.Title: relationship will not survive timerdog alamik

Posts.Content: Aug 22, 2011 07:25PM Cat123 wrote: I'm drinking wine right now!  With all the stress, don't know how I would survive without it.  Bad me.  Trying to live a healthier life however but feeling guilty.
Posts.Title: I'm fially coming out of the closet as a slouch. weesa faithfulheart

Posts.Content: Aug 22, 2011 08:19PM Cat123 wrote: Definately get a second opinion.  My first surgeon wanted me to have a lumpectomy and didn't care how my breast looked afterwards even though I had a large tumour.  I met with another surgeon and opted for a mx with recon.....which is not everyone's choice but that worked for me.  Get a second opinion.....this guy sounds too abrupt.
Posts.Title: Groan, groan, Really bad meeting with PS tarry dontworrybehappy

Posts.Content: Jan 12, 2011 09:01PM Cat123 wrote: I started on dose dense AC on Dec 22nd and had my second one last week.  I will have 4 AC followed by 4 dd Taxol.  So far, minimal side effects....yeah!  I have actually felt great.  I am on day 21 and still have a full head of hair although I have been shedding all week.  Although once I wash it again tomorrow, maybe alot will go!
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Feb 8, 2012 10:21PM Cat123 wrote: I am so sorry that you are going through this.  Big hugs to you.  I had DD ACT last year.  It will go by faster than you think.  The rads were a little harder on me but not that bad.....you can do it!  The stage is not a number or a death sentence.  I sat next to a woman during chemo that was diagnosed at stage 4 and that was nine years ago!  Stay positive...it is tough but we can all try together.
Posts.Title: 3.5 months out from dx and can't stop crying TectonicShift Califgirl12

Posts.Content: Feb 17, 2011 11:18PM Cat123 wrote: Hi everyone!  I am on dose dense ACT and have completed 4 rounds of AC and just started Taxol yesterday.  I had minimal SEs on AC....fatigue of course, some mouth sores, constipation, watery eyes and nose, metallic mouth but no nausea.  My hair started falling out at about day 15 but I didn't cut it...I have long hair.  I still have quite a bit of hair left but it looks quite funny!  I bought silk pillowcases and my hair stopped falling out!  I  have some hair and then major bald patches but it helps keeps me warm through the winter!  A great wig helps alot.  My Taxol went well yesterday and I am hoping the bone pain is mild.  The docs didn't prescribe me anything but said I could take Tylenol.  I still have oxycontin from my surgery in case it is bad.  It varies from woman to woman.
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Feb 18, 2011 01:34AM Cat123 wrote: I am praying for you and sending love and hugs to you.  This damn disease is terrible.  It sounds like you have a wonderful medical team.  If you can, try to get in touch with a naturopathic doctor as well as that will help to heal your whole body physically and mentally.  It can do wonders for you.  I have sat next to women during my chemo who are stage iv and have been alive for years with mets so do not give up hope.  You sound like a very strong woman and that is on your side.  Try natural cures as well as conventional....that is a good route to go!  Much love to you.
Posts.Title: 28 YR Old Is Looking For Support from You wwaterlilyy ibcmets

Posts.Content: Aug 22, 2011 06:47PM Cat123 wrote: Don't worry about radiation!  I've had 2 surgeries and chemo.  I was very scared before radiation too.  Cancelled my first radiation mapping appts because I was stressed out!  I did get burnt but I applied saline solution and cream and that really helped.  It is not a cakewalk but it is over before you know it.  If you want to PM me feel free!

Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: Dec 17, 2010 08:21PM Cat123 wrote: Hi all.....hey kittycat....if that is you in the brunette wig....you look amazing! The Mike Brady comment had me howling.....I start chemo next week....I have always had slightly wavy hair which i straighten....love curly hair on other people but not me....I know with my luck...my hair will grow in curly!  By the way.....I'm in Toronto so I don't know if Canada is different but apparently, your onc can write a prescription for a 'head prosthesis' meaning wig....and you can write some of the cost off in your income tax.....just like some drug prescriptions....I know this will help me out!  Make sure to check that out.
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: Jan 26, 2011 10:25PM Cat123 wrote: I'm currently doing dd ACT which I started Dec 22nd so I have had three so far.  My hair started falling out a couple of weeks ago.  I read about silk pillowcases being good for your hair so I bought one at Bed, Bath and Beyond (it was in a package called 'As Seen On Tv) for $24.95 Canadian.  It really slowed down my hair loss!  I wish I would have got it earlier.  I only have maybe 20 to 25% of my hair left but still....I was shocked.  I don't wake up with tons of hair on the pillow anymore.  Plus, I think the silk pillowcase will be good for hair re-growth because cotton and poly sheets are rough on the hair and scalp.  I have to say...I'm loving my wig!  It is alot more comfortable if you wear a stocking cap on your head with the wig overtop....not itchy and it doesn't slide around.
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: Feb 18, 2011 02:50AM Cat123 wrote: I am still undergoing chemo.  I have a fabulous wig and I wear a cap underneath it so it is not itchy.  When I was losing my hair I bought silk pillowcases and funnily enough, my hair stopped falling out!   Mind you, I only have about 20% of my hair left but I have a nice little hair covering that keeps me warm.  I have read that the silk pillowcases help with the hair regrowth because it doesn't tug on your hair

Posts.Title: How could I go for yearly mammos and end up with a 6.5cm tumour? Cat123 scuttlers

Posts.Content: Jan 27, 2011 06:30PM Cat123 wrote: Well, I am a member of the very dense breasts club.  I'm 47 so you can still have dense breasts when you're older.  If only I had known too that dense breasts make a mammo impossible to read and that it may be a precursor to cancer.  I laugh now when I see all these pink ads for getting yearly mammos because they could save your life.  Not true!
Posts.Title: How could I go for yearly mammos and end up with a 6.5cm tumour? Cat123 scuttlers

Posts.Content: Cat123 wrote: I am still feeling angry....at no one in particular but how could I diligently go for yearly mammos and end up with a 6.5cm tumour?  I felt the lump and had to go and get it checked out.  Shouldn't a mammo have picked it up?  Are mammos so inadequate? Posts.Title: How could I go for yearly mammos and end up with a 6.5cm tumour? Cat123 scuttlers

Posts.Content: Jan 27, 2011 01:03AM Cat123 wrote: I know...I do wonder what is going on.  I worked with a woman several years ago who went through bc and she told me at the time (she told lots of women) to lie to my doctor and say that my mother or aunt had breast cancer so that I would always get ultrasounds as well.  She said this because mammos didn't pick hers up either.  I can't lie though!  Sort of wished I would have now.
Posts.Title: How could I go for yearly mammos and end up with a 6.5cm tumour? Cat123 scuttlers

Posts.Content: Feb 18, 2011 01:17AM Cat123 wrote: Well, I have been telling all women to check to see if they have dense breasts and insist on ultrasounds as well as mammograms.  Many women I speak to are shocked that mammograms don't pick up breast cancer tumours as we are all told that mammograms lead to early detection of breast cancer and we know that this is not true.  I am trying to educate my girlfriends that this is not the case and with dense breasts you have to insist on ultrasound.  I wish the medical community would put dense breast gals in a different category.  It is a shame to go through years of mammos only to find out that they didn't pick up images of large tumours.  I am still angry that this is a sham in many ways.  Women need to be educated as to how this all works.  Unfortunately, we  found out when it's too late.  Makes me angry.

Posts.Content: Dec 17, 2010 05:03PM Cat123 wrote: Okay...that is good to know...thanks everyone!  Does the Decadron cause weight gain?  I think some meds do and I would like to avoid that if possible.  Planning on walking as much as I can if I feel okay.  I am very scared and nervous.  I discussed the CMF regimen with my onc a couple of weeks ago but they were not too hip on me doing that one.  It is an older regimen.  Minimal hair loss, less toxicity but longer chemo....about six months.  Because I have 4 positive nodes, they think dd ACT would be better. Is this good.....should we all go with the strongest because it really does get rid of all the cancer cells?  I know it's dumb....I had a left mx which was okay but the thought of losing my hair scares the daylights out of me....I have always had long hair....haven't had really short hair since  I was six!  The thought of looking like a cancer patient who is sick is so scary..I want to pretend I am well.....well, I feel great now!  Know I won't in a week...that is scary too!
